author: Shannon Morgan, CMA  Medical Assistant Posts: 530 Joined: Fri May 06, 2005 6:28 pm Location: Dallas, Texas. USA.
title: [no title]
content: Are you a female?  Rectoceles can be common in menopausal women, but it's not a requirement, occasionally they occur in men too   Rectocele is the wall of the rectum on the other side of the vagina is weakened and has collapsed, but they don't  really hurt, so that is probably not it.  There is also anal fissure, a tear in the rectum due to constipation, hard stools, and/or straining to have a bowel movement.   These can heal on their own, with lots of fiber in food and something like metamucil and a daily stool softener.    There are internal hemorrhoids, which are also caused by constipation, as above.  They may  bleed, and may also heal on their own the same way.  Then there is the possibility of rectal cancer.  The first three don't involve the abdomen, the last one can.  There is no way to even speculate as to the cause of your abdominal pain. Myriads of possibilities from GYN to colon problems, among others.  It is best to get examined, even though you don't really have the money.  Try a county hospital, many work on a sliding scale and charge whatever you are able to pay.  Either way, do see someone.     Shannon

content: Straining and constipation (hard stools) can often result in hemorrhoids, which can often bleed with a BM. author: Mr Smith  Guest Posts: 1 Joined: Wed Feb 23, 2005 4:00 am Location: United kingdom
title: 1/2 way through 5fu course-nasty chest infection or????
content: Hi, first a quick explanation as to where I'm at currently:  Diagnosed with bowel cancer October 2004 aged 33. Subsequent right hemiocolectomy removed growth with no spread to lymph nodes (26 tested and all clear) though it had gone into muscle of bowel wall.As the margin between healthy tissue and diseased was only approx 1 millimetre my specialist advised a 6 month course of chemo-5FU just to make sure everything nasty had been eradicated.  First 3 months went fine except usual diahorrea and occassional nausea which I believe is fairly commonplace. Also gained back weight I lost prior to surgery. Anyway the last 5 weeks or so I've been having chest pains in the lower left area of my ribcage on my left side coupled with a burning sensation there, a cough and night sweats. Oncology doc diagnosed a probable chest infection and put me on a course of Amoxycillin for a week. Felt a bit better but then the pain returned about a week later. This time also noticed  blood in my nostrils and sinuses and seemed once to cough up a little mucus streaked with blood. Subsequently had 2 chest xrays and an ECG monitor and both were clear, was prescribed further Amoxycillin and also Erythromycin for two weeks and a 2 week break from chemo.Once again started to feel a little better until I had my chemo shot last Friday and the chest pain, cough, left shoulder pain has started again.  Now being a smoker my main concern was lung cancer though my oncologist says it's highly unlikely. However this recurring chest problem is really starting to worry me as I've had no problems like this before in my life. I'm well aware that chemo can compromise your immune system but is it usual for infections of this nature to stick around for so long (i.e roughly 5 weeks)? Plus I've heard that chest xrays won't always pick up traces of lung cancer anyway. Is it worth hassling my oncologist for further tests or should I just sit it out and wait for a few weeks longer. I'm well aware that anyone recently diagnosed with cancer will naturally always assume the worst whenver they get any aches and pains so I'm in a bit of a quandry with this one and how to proceed.Any advice would be appreciated.
posted_time: Post  by Mr Smith » Wed Feb 23, 2005 4:25 am

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Chest pain
content: Thanks for posting your question here at The Lounge.  5-fluorouracil chemotherapy can at times cause heart rhythm problems, but such usually occur, if they occur at all, in older people and if the 5-fluorouracil is given as a continuous infusion over along stretch of time.  Are you getting leucovorin chemotherapy with the 5-fluorouracil?  I have had a few patients develop various side effects from the leucovoin, although leucovorin is for the most part well tolerated when given to people.  If you have not had a CAT scan of the lungs/chest, then I would consider that in order to get a good look.  Sometimes an MRI of the chest can hlp look at the chest wall/ribs (it does not look well at the lungs), especially if you can localize where in the chest you are getting your pain.  If your chest pain is at the bottom of the ribs, then one may also need to image the abdomen to make certain that something is not going on there that could be giving you chest/rib pain.  - Jeffrey A. Gordon, M.D.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi samjg, My apologies for the delayed response. Signs and symptoms of IBS may include: abdominal pain or cramping, a bloated feeling, gas, diarrhea or constipation. People with IBS may experience alternating bouts of constipation and diarrhea and mucus in the stool. Signs and symptoms of IBS worsen with stress. The exact cause of this condition is unknown. It does affect more women than men. According to medical studies it does not appear to be hereditary although other family members may have similar symptoms. I hope this is helpful. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: ibs? hla-b27 positive
content: Dear Guest,   If you are not having heavy bleeding, i don't think you have to go to the er and you can wait till you see your doctor in the morning but if for any reason, he is not going to able to get you in, you have to go to the er or let him admit you to the hospital.  The red color in the stools could be caused by something as simple as hemorrhoids but can prove serious as well, that is why you have to be evaluated.  If the bleeding increases at any time, you have to go to the er.  With irritbale bowel syndrome, you should not be having any bleeding. i am not familiar with elderberries and what they can do to one's bowel habits.  Having clay color stools with blood on top with a history of pancreatic mass may be indicative of someting serious such as pancreatic cancer. But for pancreatic cancer to cause clay color stools as well, there should be some obstruction causing jaundice.  You could also have an obstruction caused by a gall stone that passed and caused some inury but usually this is not the clinical presentation. Clinical presentation is usually a right upper quadrant pain followed by jaundice and then relief of jaundice when and if the stone passes and then if the stone is large enough to block the passage of stools from small to large intestines, it will cause a small bowel obstruction (a condition known as gall stone ileus).  My recommendation is to have the ct scan repeated, may be get an mri and/or an ercp or mrcp if available where you live.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

title: Re: ibs? hla-b27 positive
content: Dear Guest,   ercp stands for endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography and it is basically doing an endoscopy with a special type of an endoscope and then inject a dye in the bile ducts (passages to the gall bladder and liver) and in the pancreatic duct and then have x-ray pictures to see whether there is any obstruction or not.   mrcp stands for magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography which is an mri on the bile ducts. author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello, As Dr. Yasser said your bleeding issue should be addressed as soon as possible. If it turns out that your bleeding is caused by something as simple as hemorrhoids then you probably won't need any further investigations. If however, the cause is not clear a search for a cause will include evaluation of all your GI system including re-evaluation of the suspicious pancreatic mass (possibly by another new CT scan).   In your case I wouldn't worry about it being an aggressive cancer (adenocarcinoma) since the median survival for this disease without treatment is no longer than 3 months and it usually does not pass so calmly. Again I agree with Dr. Yasser's assertion that for pancreatic cancer to cause clay color stools, there should be some obstruction causing jaundice, which does not seem to be the case.  That said however, it should be stated that there are many other (less harmful pancreatic tumors) which can stay for years with minimal symptoms. The so called neuroendocrine tumors are a clear entity whose biological behaviour has no correlation with the pathology. Some of these pancreatic tumors secrete hormones while others do not. Median survival without treatment can be as high as 10 to 20 years or even higher.  Best regards,

Histology showed adenocarcinoma, mildly differentiated.. Dukes B2 staging. Post op am doing very well. My question is do you think adjuvant chemotherapy is indicated in my case to mininize risk of recurrance and  lessen the chance of spread from original. My mother is dying from liver mets from having had the same cancer as myself, and her father also died of Ca colon.  I have read a lot, and leterature seems to sway favourably toward adjuvant chemo in pts with Dukes B.  Please comment, Regards, Floss from New Zealand
posted_time: Post  by floss » Fri Jul 30, 2004 4:27 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hi Floss, Adjuvant chemotherapy for Dukes C colon cancer (lymph node involvement) is well established. However, the benefits of chemotherapy for Dukes B tumors is not known. Trials have not shown a benefit in terms of survival for those with Dukes B colorectal cancer who have received chemotherapy. That said however, there is a strong possibility that a subset of patients with Duke's B staging may benefit. We don't know the what the profile for this subset is, so the trend is for many doctors to evaluate each patient with Duke's B cancer individually. Those with poor prognostic factors will have a higher incidence of recurrence. Hence, many opt to give these patients adjuvant chemotherapy on a rather emperical basis. In your case some would consider age <40 years as a poor prognostic factor warranting chemotherapy.  Other poor prognostic factors include: Cancers that have obstructed the bowel,  Cancers that have perforated the wall of the colon, or  Cancers that have adhered to structures outside the intestine.   Another important factor is your family history. Approximately 5% of all colon (large bowel) cancers are directly caused by inherited genetic abnormalities. These hereditary colon cancers often feature colonic polyps or growths that eventually become cancerous. There are several kinds, including familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) and a variant called Gardner's syndrome. Another type, hereditary non-polyposis colon cancer (HNPCC), features few if any polyps. Relatively rare hereditary conditions such as Peutz-Jeghers syndrome and juvenile polyposis are not cancer or precancerous conditions but confer on the patient a greater than normal risk of developing colon cancer. Many families with higher than normal rates of colon cancer have one or more of these conditions. While non-hereditary ("sporadic") colon cancer rarely occurs before age 40, hereditary colon cancers often occur in younger people.   FAP has been associated with poor outcome as compared to those with HNPCC.

author: lanesharon  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sun Feb 16, 2003 11:45 am Location: AZ  Contact:   Contact lanesharon       Website   Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: I think that this depends on what the doctor meant.  Some will use incorrect terminology.  In the Dorland Diction (Merck Website), nodule (nodulus) means a small knot or node.  That sounds relatively solid to me.  It also means a minute collection of tissue.  Polyp means a morbid excrescence, or protruding growth, from mucous membrane; classically applied to a growth on the mucous membrane of the nose, the term is now applied to such protrusions from any mucous membrane.  This description gives me the impression that it is mucinous or much more flexible physically.  I am a cancer advocate, working for an organization that helps pediatric patients and rare adult cancer patients.  What I am doing is showing you how confusing some of this can be in the cancer world.  Terminology and nomenclature can get a little 'mixed up' to say the least.  So, the best thing that you can do is to call that doctor and ask him/her what they meant when they used those words.  That would be the simplest solution and would alleviate the worry that you must be feeling right now.

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Colon cancer
content: Lynette,  Thanks for  your post to The Doctor's Lounge.  Usually cancers that develop in family members when those family members are elder are of less a risk factor than if those cancers developed in patient 50 years old or younger.  The standard colorectal cancer screening guidelines concerning colonoscopies ("real" ones, not "virtual") is that for the average person, colonsocopies should begin at age 50.  If there are first-degree family members who developed colorectal cancer ata young age, then screening can begin earlier.  In this case, a more detailed family history pertaining to cancer is in order.  If there is only one family member who developed colorectal cancer below the age of 50 years, then one could consider doing a screening colonoscopy before the age of 50 (i.e.- at age 40 years).  This is an issue that should be discussed with your husband's physician and if need be, an opinion from a Gastroenterologist (these are the spcecialists who usually do colonoscopies,  although some General Internists and Surgeons do them as well.

title: 5-FU vs Capecitabine for stage 2 colon cancer
content: Would like to know what's your opinion of choosing either one of the two options above for a 64+ year old female patient, non-smoker who was treated with stage 1 breast cancer 24 years ago (16 doses radiotherapy). Her father died of rectal cancer at the age of 75+  The tumour was discovered during a colonoscopy (about 2.5 cm, resulted in a stricture) and has since been surgically removed, with negative margin; negative nodes. CT scan & chest X-ray didn't indicate any signs of metasis. During the surgery, a cirrosis nodule was removed from the liver. Oncologist recommended CEA upon completion of chemotherapy, colonoscopy after 1 year post-operation.  Would appreciate your response.  Many thanks
posted_time: Post  by Caregiver- » Fri Aug 29, 2003 3:27 am

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Colon cancer
content: Caregiver,  I cannot fully respond to the decision to use chemotherapy because I do not have all of the details of the surgically removed colon cancer.  It is good news that the cancer was removed with margins being clear of cancer.  It is also good news that the colon cancer was not found to have any associated lymph node spread.  From the subject heading of your post, I gather that the colon cancer was staged as Stage II or what is also referred to as Duke's Stage B.  There are a few items of importance that I would like to know:  1.)  How deep through the bowel wall did the ccancer invade? 2.)  Were there any associated findings of bowel obstruction or bowel perforation?  If a decision is reached to give adjuvant (post-operative ) chemotherapy, then a standard chemotherapy regimen would include 5-fluorouracil (this can be given in several different ways).  Off of a clinical research study, I do not use capecitabine (tradename is Xeloda).  Although capecitabine behaves like a continuous infusion of 5-fluorouracil, its use is not standard and as far as I know, has not been compared head to head to 5-fluorouracil in the adjuvant treatment setting of colon cancer.  However, I am aware of colleagues of mine who have used it in just this setting, as opposed to its more standard use in adbanced stages of the disease, where it has been compared in a randomized study to 5-fluorouracil..  In my practice, I recommend a follow-up colonoscopy at 6-8 months from the surgery (usually this occurs after a 6-8 month course of adjuvant chemotherapy has been given), then I recommend it in another 6 months, then on an annual basis.  However, there is no one standard practice recommendation, and different practice patterns exist.  I prefer the initial colonoscopy at 6-8 months in order to check the surgical anastomosis site in the colon.  If the pre-operative CEA level was eleavted, then I follow it after chemotherapy.  Sometimes, chemotherapy can artificially elevate its level, so I don't check it during chemotherapy.  However, a post-operative level should be checked before chemotherapy so as to check that an elevated pre-operative level has normalized.  If it remains elevated post-operatively, then I am concerned about residual disease or another undetected site of disease.  Beware that cigaretet smoking can artificially elevate its level.  I obtain a CAT scan (and sometimes also a PET scan) after chemotherapy is done, then in another 6 months, then just on an annual basis there after.  Hope that this helps.

With these symptoms, is it possible to determine what stage the colon cancer is in.  Is having symptoms a sign of being in the latter stages of the disease? posted_time: Post  by Krissy » Fri Aug 08, 2003 1:26 am

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Colon cancer
content: Krissy,  There is no clear association between symtpoms and the stage of a cancer.  First, testing must done to determine if indeed you have a colon cancer.  If a colon cancer is found, then scans (CAT scans and bone scans; sometimes a PET scan) are done to identify as best as possible where the cancer is and where it isn't.  If the cancer can be removed, then the surgeon will remove nearby lymph nodes to see if the cancer has spread there.  The surgeon will also take a look inside the abdomen/pelvis to check for evidence that the cancer has spread.   I have seen patients with early stage colon cancer present with severe abdominal pain due to the cancer blocking the colon.  Ihave also seen patients with wide spread disease present with very few symptoms.  Take care.  Jeffrey A. Gordon, M.D.

author: pattilou1
title: Stage 3, High dose vs low dose?
content: Hello, WOULD LIKE TO KNOW WHERE WE CAN FIND MORE STATISTICAL RESEARCH ON THE USE OF LOW DOSE VERSUS HIGH DOSE LEUCOVORIN WITH 5-FU.  WHAT IS YOUR RECOMMENDATION FOR PATIENT WITH STAGE 3 AND FOUR OUT OF FIVE LYMPH NODES INVOLVED IN REGARDS TO THE DOSAGE AND WHY?  THANKS,
posted_time: Post  by pattilou1 » Tue Mar 04, 2003 11:13 am

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: [no title]
content: Pattilou1,  My apologies for a delay in responding to your post.  In the U.S. there are two standard chemotherapy regimens using 5-fluorouracil and leucovorin chemotherapy to treat colon cancer that has spread to the regional lymph nodes (Stage III or Stage C): 1.) the 5-FU and the leucovorin are given five days in a row every month (the leucovorin is low-dose at 20 mg per meter squared) and 2.) the 5-FU and the leucovorin are given once a week for 6 weeks in a row every 8 weeks (theleucovorin is high-dose at 500 mg per meter squared).  Although in Europe continuous infusion of 5-FU is given more often than is used in the U.S., even then the leucovorin is usually high-dose in nature.  The two different 5-FU and leucovorin regimens that I mentioned above (termed the Mayo regimen and the Roswell Park regimen, respectviely) are equivalent to each other in their effectiveness, but do have somewhat different toxicities.  I find, as do many Medical Oncologists who treat patients with colon cancer, that the Roswell Park regimen is tolerated better than the Mayo regimen, especially in older people.  There has not been a formal comparison of low-dose versus high-dose leucovorin when used as part of the Roswell Park regimen in the post-operative setting of Stage III colon cancer, as far as I am aware.  I am aware of a British study that compared high-dose leucovorin to low-dose leucovorin as part of chemotherapy treatment in the setting of metastatic or advanced Stage IV disease.  In this one trial, it appeared that there were no differences in the effectiveness of the chemotherapies.  There seemed to be less side effects with the use of low-dose leucovorin.  However, there are other studies that report more effectiveness by using the high-dose leucovorin compared to the low-dose leucovorin the Stage IV colon cancer.  In treating Stage III colon cancer, I use the published Roswell Park regimen that uses high-dose leucovorin.  Without any other data about using low-dose leucovorin in Stage III disease, I would stay with a published and time-tested chemotherapy regimen.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear VK, sorry for your father but in reality I am so concerned about his general condition since he is 78 years old. I have explained in the same section about this disease and in particular metastaic and advanced cases. In general patient of colon cancer with metastases that are potentially resectable should undergo definitive surgical resection of the primary tumo. Consideration should be given to preoperative therapy. In such cases, conversion to resectability has been seen in up to 75% of cases.Then the patient should be reassessed for respectability and further management.this is in reality the only way to acheive a possible 5 year survival in such cases for more tahn 20%.  Other wise in cases of inoperability due to general condition or extensive metstatic disease treatment is of palliative role. Palliative surgery, RT, and palliative chemotherapy are of considerable approaches according to the situation. 5-FU remains the mainstay of chemotherapy treatment for colorectal cancer. However the increased response rates and prolonged progression-free survival seen  with the combinations of 5-FU, leucovorin, and either irinotecan or oxaliplatin has introduced new options for the treatment of this disease. patients should be encouraged to participate in well-designed clinical trials involving new regimens whenever possible. Best regards

content: Dear dido  the informations you wrote are very deficient to give you an answer about the possible line of therapy he might be eligible for.  I would like to know what  kind of chemotheraypy regimens did your patient received and is it a metastatic disease or there is a local disease in addition. Also are theses metastatic lesions resctable or not(anatomic site, size, their number in addition to the patient general condition).  since surgery is the only universally accepted potentially curative treatment for colorectal cancer, surgical resection for primary, recurrent and or metastatic lesions is to be considred whenever possible. The 5 year survival for resection of solitary or combination etastases exceeds 20%. However, this is a general approach to patients with recurrent and or metastatic siease:  1. Surgical resection of isolated metastases (liver, lung, ovaries).  2. Palliative surgical interference for primary and  secondary sites (for bleeding & obstruction).  3. Palliative Chemotherapy. Clinical trials evaluating new drugs and biologic therapy should be considered for those patients whenever possible. 4.  Radiation therapy to the primary or metastatic tumor to palliate bleeding, obstruction, or pain Local control therapy: Patients with limited (3 or less) hepatic metastases, resection may be considered with 5-year survival rates of 20% to 40%. For those with unresectable, cryosurgical ablation has been associated with long-term tumour control. Other local ablative techniques that have been used to manage liver metastases include embolization and interstitial radiation therapy.  Hepatic intra-arterial chemotherapy with floxuridine for liver metastases has produced higher overall response rates but no improvement in survival when compared to systemic chemotherapy. The use of the combination of intraarterial chemotherapy with hepatic irradiation, especially  focal radiation of metastatic lesions, is under evaluation. Patients with limited pulmonary metastases, and patients with both pulmonary and hepatic metastases, may also be considered for surgical resection, with possible 5-year survival in highly selected patients. Systemic therapy: In metastatic and recurrent colon cancer, chemotherapy has been used for palliation, with 5-FU-based regimen considered to be standard  treatment (can be used as either single agent or in combination with leucovorin and irinotecan).  Irinotecan (CPT-11) is a topoisomerase-I inhibitor with a 10% to 20% partial response rate . It is now considered standard 2 nd line therapy for patients with metastatic disease who do not respond to or progress on 5-FU.  Oxaliplatin, alone or combined with 5-FU and leucovorin, has shown promising activity in previously treated and untreated patients with metastatic colorectal cancer and in patients with 5-FU refractory disease  Tomudex, is a specific thymidylate synthase inhibitor which has demonstrated activity similar to that of bolus 5-FU and leucovorin.   Capecitabine, an oral fluoropyrimidine carbamate, has been compared to 5-FU plus leucovorin in a phase III study. The drug has a higher response rate , although survival, duration of response, and time-to-disease progression were similar. It may serve to substitute for 5-FU plus leucovorin as a less toxic single agent or in combinations. best of wishes
